In this work, zinc supported composite catalysts were evaluated in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide, limonene oxidation, and one pot synthesis of campholenic aldehyde from α-pinene. The composites materials were synthesized using CaCO3 and a mixture of aluminium and magnesium sources as the inorganic phases and the bisphenol A glycerolate dimethacrylate / triethylene glycol dimethacrylate polymerized mixture as the polymeric organic phases. The materials were characterized by NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, XRD, Py-FTIR, XPS, ICP, TEM and SEM-EDX. Mainly Lewis acid sites were identified by Py-FTIR analysis of BTAlMg and Zn-BTAlMg. The basicity of BTCa and Zn-BTCa materials was identified by CO2-TPD. Over Zn-BTCa, α-pinene conversion of 73 % and campholenic aldehyde selectivity of 90 % were obtained. The oxidation of limonene over Zn-BTCa yielded a conversion of 36 % with a selectivity of 92 % and 8 % towards 1,2-limonene epoxide and 8,9-limonene epoxide, respectively. The isomerization of β-pinene epoxide over Zn-BTAlMg with dimethyl carbonate, gave 89 % β-pinene epoxide conversion and 100 % selectivity to myrtanal. The synthesized catalysts did not show leaching under tested catalytic reactions. After four reuses, the product selectivity did not significantly changed and the conversion decreased 7 % and 11 % in the oxidation of α-pinene and isomerization of β-pinene epoxide, respectively. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Campholenic aldehyde Composite materials Myrtanal One-pot reaction Terpenes Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The use of heterogeneous catalysts allows for a reduction in pollution by decreasing the stages of the process, transforming contaminating compounds into non-polluting ones, and reducing process costs. When the goal is to improve catalytic activity, selectivity, catalyst lifetime, process costs decrease, and support design are some of the factors to be considered [1]. Traditionally engineered materials, including carbon fibers, layered solid platelets, nanospheres, as well as films and membranes, are extensively utilized as carriers for active metals. Nonetheless, these conventional supported metal catalysts exhibit notable limitations, particularly issues related to the undesirable sintering of active metal sites, which leads to a reduction in catalytic effectiveness. Moreover, when the catalyst particles rub between each other, attrition occurs and some metal nanoparticles detach from the surface, resulting in loss of active sites and an additional decline of the catalytic activity [2]. Consequently, the development of innovative catalysts that can address these fundamental challenges associated with supported metal catalysts remains a significant hurdle within this domain [3]. The authors synthesized a new composite material that can be used as supports to obtain egg shell catalysts [4]. Composite supports are made up of a matrix with mixed inorganic-organic composition characteristics providing particularities that improve industrial processes. The combination of its dual hydrophilic (inorganic phase) and hydrophobic (polymeric phase) properties allows obtaining a minimum and homogeneous thickness of metallic active phase on the surface of the support using simple metal deposition methods. Egg shell catalysts are widely used in a variety of chemical reactions [4]. Terpenes can be transformed into commercially important compounds to produce fragrances, perfumes, flavors, and pharmaceuticals. These transformations involve reactions of isomerization, hydration, condensation, hydroformylation, hydrogenation, cyclization, oxidation, rearrangement and/or ring contraction/enlargement [5]. The monoterpenes α- and β-pinene are bicyclic compounds found in several essential oils such as pine and eucalyptus resins; due to the CC double bond, it can be transformed into many useful compounds in the fine chemical industry [5,6]. α- and β-pinene are the main components of turpentine oil, a useful by-product of wood and paper industries. From β-pinene epoxide isomerization, the main products are myrtanal, myrtenol, and perillyl alcohol [7,8], Fig. 1 a; α-pinene oxide isomerizes to campholenic aldehyde that is a compound of interest to produce fragrances [9], Fig. 1b. The rearrangement of α- and β-pinene epoxides and their selectivity are affected by the type of acidity (Lewis or Brönsted) and the polarity of the solvent [8]; the isomerization of β-pinene oxide to myrtanal is promoted by Lewis acidic species while Brönsted acids give mainly perillyl alcohol and myrtenol [10]. Table S1 shows the different heterogeneous catalysts that have been reported for the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide, Fe-modified mesoporous supports (SBA-15) have reported a selectivity to myrtanal of 100 % and 85 % using toluene and tert‑butanol as solvent, respectively [8]. Over Mo/SBA-15, a selectivity of 63 % to perillyl alcohol using hexane as solvent was found [11]. When beta zeolite was modified with iron, the selectivity towards perillyl alcohol was 66 % using dimethyl sulfoxide as solvent [12], if the solid was modified with Sn, selectivity of 66 % to myrtanal with toluene as solvent was observed [13]. Over Zr-beta zeolite, 94 % of selectivity to myrtanal was obtained, using acetonitrile as solvent [14]. Using natural zeolite and toluene as solvent, selectivity towards myrtanal was 23 % and 47 % to perillyl alcohol [15]. No zinc catalysts have been reported for the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide. For oxidation reactions, magnesium oxide has been reported as a suitable heterogeneous catalyst for substrates such as β-pinene [16], limonene [17] (Fig. 1c) and styrene [18] under mild reaction conditions (323 K and 2 h) via a Payne system in presence of H2O2 and acetonitrile, and with water and acetone as solvents. The reaction involves the formation of peroxyacetimidic acid as the active intermediate oxidant, which is formed by activating H2O2 with acetonitrile through a nucleophilic attack by perhydroxyl anion species (HOO-) on the nitrile, acting as basic OH- groups [18,19]. H2O2 reacts with acetonitrile to form peroxyacetamide acid which acts as an oxygen atom donor to the double bond of the terpenes. In addition, acetamide is formed as a by-product of the reaction. Although acetonitrile can act as a solvent, improvements in the activity of the reaction have been described by adding external solvent and catalyst activators. For example, acetone and an excess of H2O have been shown to increase the activity for the epoxidation of styrene, using hydrotalcite as a catalyst [18]. Obtaining campholenic aldehyde in a single step (one-pot reaction) is of great interest due to reduced costs, synthesis time, separation methods and environmental impact [20]. The synthesis of campholenic aldehyde by one-pot reactions from α-pinene over Ti-HMS, and with acetonitrile as solvent and TBHP as oxidizing agent has been reported, with a conversion of 32 % and selectivity towards campholenic aldehyde of 82 % (30 mL acetonitrile, 100 mg catalyst, 5 mmol α-pinene, 5 mmol tert‑butyl hydroperoxide) [21]. Other authors reported a α-pinene conversion of 90 % and selectivity of 90 % towards campholenic aldehyde using praseodymium oxide as catalyst (100 mg catalyst, 5 mmol α-pinene and 10 mL chloroform as solvent and under an air flow of 5 mL min-1 for 12 h) [22]. Different catalysts have been reported in the epoxidation of olefins: methyltrioxorhenium, transition metal complexes with β-diketones, copper salts, porphyrins, minerals such as metal oxides and hydrotalcites, and supported metals such as Mo, Co, Cu and Mn, among others [23–25]. In this contribution two new composite materials named BTAlMg and BTCa, as supports of the catalysts were used. Composites were synthetized using bisphenol A glycerolate dimethacrylate (BGMA) and triethylene glycol dimethacrylate (TEG) as polymeric phase, and benzoyl peroxide (BPO) as a temperature-activated radical initiator. Besides, alumina modified with magnesium or calcium carbonate were incorporated as inorganic load to obtain the composite supports. As Zn and ZnO are amphoteric species [26], because they can act as nucleophiles (electron and base donors) and electrophiles (electron and acid acceptors), they are useful in the Payne system that requires a base for the formation of the oxidant specie [16–18]. Furthermore, Zn(II) salts act as Lewis acids [27], for the selective isomerization of monoterpene epoxides to aldehydes [10]. The obtained catalysts, Zn-BTAlMg and Zn-BTCa, were tested for the epoxidation of α-pinene and limonene using the Payne system; furthermore, the materials were used for β-pinene epoxide isomerization. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Reactants were used as received. R-(+)-α-pinene (Sigma Aldrich 98 %), β-pinene epoxide (96 % w / w, synthesized according reported procedure [16]), R-(+)-limonene (Sigma Aldrich 97 %), hexane (Honeywell 98.63 %), cyclohexane (Mallinckrodt, 100 %), dioxane (Panrec 99.5 %), acetone (Supelco 99.8 %), acetonitrile (Mallinckrodt 99.9 %), ethyl acetate (Panreac 99.5 %), Zn(NO3)2 .6H2O (Panreac 98 %), bisphenol A glycerolate dimethacrylate (Aldrich, MQ200, ≥99 %), triethylene glycol dimethacrylate (Aldrich 99 %), benzoyl peroxide (Aldrich, MQ200), γ-alumina (Ketjen CK-300), CaCO3 (Anedra, purity 98.6 %), MgSO4 ·7H2O (Anedra, purity 99.8 %). 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Composite synthesis In the preparation of the composite materials (organic-inorganic), each support was prepared by copolymerization and intimate mixture of organic and inorganic phases following a technique previously developed [4,28]. Fig. 2 presents a diagram of the preparation sequence of the composite supports. Both supports contain the same organic phase, which was synthesized as follows: a mixture of TEG and BGMA monomers (1:1 molar ratio) and BPO (benzoyl peroxide) as a polymeric initiator, were mixed during 30 min and obtaining BT material. In this point, the inorganic particles are added in a 1:1 (inorganic: monomers) weight ratio according to the desired properties for the final support. For the synthesis of BTAlMg, the inorganic phase was γ-alumina in powder, 200 meshes, previously calcined 3 h at 823 K in air, modified with Mg (0.322 g MgSO4·7H2O/γ-alumina) [29]. For BTCa, the inorganic phase was CaCO3. In each support, both organic and inorganic phases come into intimate contact in a flask and mixed for 1 h. Besides, the materials were degassed and extruded into cylinders of 2 mm of diameter, then were placed in a stove at 393 K for 1 h to activate the BPO initiator that started the polymerization. The final material obtained was called composite support and is made up of a continuous polymer phase and a discontinuous inorganic phase. This material has high mechanical and attrition resistance, desirable properties in heterogeneous catalysts [4,28]. Then, BTAlMg and BTCa were dried at room temperature and finally ground to powder (mesh 170). 2.2.2 Synthesis of Zn supported catalyst Zinc was impregnated on the composite supports according to reported method [30] with some modifications, 1 g of BTCa or BTAlMg supports were suspended in 50 mL of the aqueous zinc solution (0.068 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O). Then, the suspension was heated at 363 K for 90 min and 500 rpm. Upon completion of this process, it was cooled up to 303 K and a 5 M NaOH solution was added dropwise until pH ∼ 11; then the suspension was heated at 353 K, 700 rpm for 1 h. After the impregnation was completed, the sample was left for 24 h at room temperature without stirring. Finally, the material was washed with distilled water up to pH ∼ 7 and dried in a convective oven at 353 K for 8 h. The obtained catalysts were named Zn-BTCa and Zn-BTAlMg. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The metal loadings of samples previously digested in sulfuric acid, was determined by atomic emission spectroscopy with Inductive Plasma (ICP-OES) using a Perkin Elmer OPTIMA 2100 DV equipment. Py-FTIR analyses were performed by transmission on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 65 FT-IR spectrometer using an MCT detector, pretreating the sample with a flow of He (13 mL min-1) up to 493 K during 30 min and cooled down; pyridine (Py) was adsorbed at 303 K for 60 min and then desorbed between 313 and 493 K. The morphology of the samples was observed by vacuum emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a DENTON VACUUM Desk IV and a JSM-6490LV microscope. The sample was coated with a thin layer of gold, fixed on graphite tape for analysis and images were taken at an accelerating voltage of 11.3 kV. Elemental analysis was performed using an X-Ray microprobe-EDX (reference INCA PentaFETx3 Oxford Instruments). NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD analyses were performed on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2290 instrument; the samples were treated at 473 K for 90 min with He flow (50 mL min-1), ammonia was adsorbed at 323 K and then desorbed by increasing the temperature at 10 K min-1 up to 493 K. The TCD signal was calibrated with ammonia and carbon dioxide of known composition, and quantification of acidity (μmol NH3 g-1) and basicity (μmol CO2 g-1 was performed using Eq. (1). (1) n D e s = 10 − 6 * V ˙ H e V m * 1 β * ∫ T 0 T i C i d T Where n D e s are the moles of desorbed ammonia or carbon dioxide, V ˙ H e is the volumetric flow rate of carrier gas in mL min-1, Vm is the molar volume in mL of one mole of gas at standard conditions (1 atm and 273.15 K), β is the heating rate in K min-1 and C i is the concentration in ppm. X-ray Diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out in an Empyrean PANalytical diffractometer working at 40 kV and 45 mA and using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm). The diffraction patterns were registered within the 2θ range between 15° < 2θ < 75°, at a scanning rate of 2° min−1. To calculate the apparent size of the crystal from XRD data (dXRD ), the Debye-Scherrer equation [31], Eq. (2), was used: (2) d X R D = B λ Δ ( 2 θ ) C O S θ where: dXRD is the crystal apparent size (nm), λ is the wavelength of applied radiation (nm), θ is the diffraction angle (degrees), Δ(2θ) is the average width of Debye-Scherrer line (rad) and B is the Scherrer's constant that is 0.9. The particle size distributions were obtained by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) in a JEOM-2100 Plus electron microscope equipment with an acceleration voltage of 100 kV and HRTEM mode. The samples were suspended in ethanol and then sonicated for 15 min. A drop of this suspension was placed on a 400 mesh copper grid with Formvar/ CARBON FILM and monitored. A set of digital images were taken to identify the phases and measure the diameters of the particles. Digital Micrograph software was used to obtain particle size distributions. The average particle size (dTEM ) of the samples determined by TEM were calculated using Eq. (3): (3) d T E M = ∑ n i d i 3 ∑ n i d i 2 Where ni is the number of particles with particle size di . The X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) technique was used to determine the electronic state of surface species following the Zn 2p, Ca 2p, Mg 1s, O 1s, C 1s and Al 2p. The reference signals were the BE (binding energy) of Al 2p at 74.7 eV and the Ca 2p3/2 at 346.8 eV, corresponding to the BTAlMg and BTCa supports, respectively [30]. Samples were dried at 373 K and measured in VG-Microtech Multilab equipment with MgKα (hυ: 1253.6 eV) and an energy flow of 50 eV. During the data acquisition the analysis pressure was constant (5.10–7 Pa). Areas under the peaks were estimated by calculating the integral of each peak after subtracting the Shirley background and fitting the experimental peak to a combination of Lorentzian and Gaussian lines of 30–70 % proportions. 2.4 Catalytic tests Isomerization of β-pinene epoxide was evaluated in 2 mL vials covered with inert silicon septa and immersed in a Radley tech hotplate with magnetic stirring. In a typical experiment, the catalyst (25, 35, 50 mg) was mixed with 0.25 mmol of the substrate in 1 mL of solvent (cyclohexane, hexane, ethyl acetate, acetone, dimethyl carbonate or 1,4-dioxane) and the suspension was heated at 363 K and stirred at 750 rpm for the selected time (2, 6 and 24 h). The epoxidation of α-pinene and limonene were conducted in 2 mL vials covered with inert silicon septa immersed in a Radley tech hot plate under magnetic stirring using the Payne system. In a typical experiment (323 K, 750 rpm and 2 h), a substrate: H2O2: CH3CN: acetone: H2O: catalyst mass ratio of 1: 0.86: 15.35: 19.17: 29.41: 1.66 was used. At the end of the reaction, manganese (II) oxide was added to decompose the excess of H2O2. The products were identified by gas chromatography using an Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph with FID and Agilent 5975C mass detector, using He as carrier gas. A silica HP-5MS capillary column (30 m, 0.25 mm, 0.25 µm) and FID detector were used. The velocity and flow rate of the carrier gas was 30.5 cm s-1 and 2.2 mL min-1, respectively. The oven temperature was 343 K for 1 min and firstly increased up to 363 K (10 K min-1) for 0.5 min, secondly raised up to 383 K (10 K min-1) for 0.5 min; thirdly, heated up to 403 K (10 K min-1) for 0.5 min and finally warmed up to 433 K (15 K min-1) for 1 min. The injection volume was 1 μL in split mode (25:1) with injector temperature of 523 K. Compounds identification was performed using the NIST database 5. Conversion and selectivity were determined using Eqs. (4) and (5), respectively. (4) % C o n v e r s i o n = ∑ A p r o d u c t o s ∑ A p r o d u c t o s + A t α o r β − p i n e n e e p o x i d e * 100 (5) % S e l e c t i v i t y = ( A t ) p r o d u c t ∑ A p r o d u c t o s * 100 where At and Aproducts correspond to the area at time t and the area of the obtained products, respectively. 2.5 Leaching and reuse rests To evaluate heterogeneity, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture after 12 min of reaction using a pore size of 0.45 µm Advantec brand syringe filter; an aliquot was taken and analyzed by MS-GC. The filtrate was left at the reaction conditions for further time and analyzed by MS-GC at 2, 4, 6 and 8 h. For reusing test, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min, washed with 1 mL of acetone at 323 K and dried at 373 K during 2 h. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 Acidity and basicity Acidity is an important characteristic of the materials used for opening epoxides [33]. High yields of myrtanal are obtained with the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide in the presence of Lewis acid sites [21]. Fig. 3 shows the spectra of desorbed pyridine at 313 K for BTAlMg and Zn-BTAlMg samples. The desorbed bands observed at 1444 cm-1, 1575 cm-1, and 1590 cm-1 are characteristic of Lewis acidic sites, which are provided by the incorporation of Mg (II) in the support while the peak at 1489 cm-1 is characteristic of mixture of Lewis and Brönsted acidic sites [34–37]. Besides, the desorbed pyridine band at 1540 cm-1 is characteristic of Brönsted acid sites [32], and is observed on the fresh support BTAlMg, disappearing on the catalyst Zn-BTAlMg, as a consequence of the incorporation of the Zn(II) Lewis sites replacing the Brönsted sites. The increase of Lewis acidic sites of the catalyst respect to the fresh support could be attributed to the incorporation of zinc in the solid because this metal specifically contributes to this type of acid site [38]. Finally, Zn-BTCa and BTCa materials did not show any signal that allows us to distinguish Lewis or Brönsted sites, probably due to the basic characteristics of the CaCO3 present in the support in a large quantity. When Zn is added, Lewis acid sites are being generated, necessary for the reaction, but they are not visible in the Py-FTIR spectrum, since Zn, being a hard acid and Py an intermediate base, would be interacting so weakly (or null) that it is impossible to see the signal [39]. The acidity strength is classified according to the NH3 desorption temperature as weak acidity (373–493 K), medium acidity (493 - 673 K) and strong acidity (673 - 873 K) [40]. As the composite materials are stable up to 493 K [41], the acidity strength of the materials (BTAlMg and Zn-BTAlMg) were evaluated by NH3-TPD, in which low total acidity was determined between 323 - 473 K. Fig. S3 shows the experimental signals and the deconvolution of the respective desorption peaks for each material, with a higher coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.95, and the quantification of the acidity was performed by Eq. (1). It has been reported that γ-Al2O3 and alumina modified with Mg present low and medium acid sites [29,42]. In accordance with different authors the peaks of weak acidity can be attributed to Lewis acid sites [43,44]. A slight increase (ca. 14 %) in the total acidity after the addition of Zn in Zn-BTAlMg (150.3 µmolNH3 g-1) respect to BTAlMg (132 µmolNH3 g-1) was observed. The increase in acidity was attributed to the presence of Zn species, responsible for different types of Lewis acid sites [38]. During the synthesis of the catalyst at pH ∼11, the remaining Brönsted acidic groups of the Mg modified alumina support, would transfer the proton of the surface OH- groups (Brönsted acidic site) to the NaOH solvent (basic Brönsted site), and simultaneously the remaining oxide sites (Lewis basic site) would bond to Zn(II), a Lewis acidic site. The basicity of the materials (BTCa and Zn-BTCa) was evaluated by CO2-TPD, a low total basicity was determined between 323 - 473 K. Fig. S4 shows the experimental signals and deconvolution of the respective desorption peaks for each material, with an upper coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.93, and basicity quantification was performed using Eq. (1). A carbon dioxide desorption peak is determined around 385 K, which is associated with weak basic sites [45], mainly the predominant basic sites in the material is attributed to the presence of CaCO3. The basicity of the material is related to the presence of ZnO, as it has been verified by other authors with the presence of CO2 desorption peaks at around 353- 370 K [46]. In addition, there was no significant change in total CO2 desorption between the two materials, probably because the supported amount of zinc was very low. 3.1.2 FTIR analysis Fig. 4 shows the FTIR analysis of BTAlMg and Zn-BTAlMg materials. The band observed at 603 cm-1 is attributed to the bending vibrations of Al-O [47], the band 964 cm-1 is attributed to the presence of quadrilateral sites by Al3+ in the cubic structure of oxide ions in gamma phases [48], which is not observed in Zn-BTAlMg. The 664 cm-1 band is characteristic to the presence of MgO [49]. The slightly shift of the bands for Zn-BTAlMg catalyst to higher number wave of some peaks in the region 1000 – 1800 cm-1 and ∼2900 cm-1 can be attributed to higher interactions due to the presence of Zn species. The peak at 1606 cm-1 indicates -OH bending, it is more pronounced in ZnBTAlMg than in the support. Similarly, the peaks at 1391 and 1450 cm-1 are likely due to CO2 absorption. The broad band in the region 2750 - 3750 cm-1 is due to OH stretching of the absorbed water molecule [50], also from alumina and zinc oxide surfaces [51]. Fig. 5 shows the FTIR analysis of BTCa and Zn-BTCa materials, which shows the band at 876 cm-1 that is characteristic of the bending vibration of the CO bond, the band at 1792 cm-1 is attributed to the C=O vibrations of CaCO3 [52]. The 712 cm-1 band is characteristic of CaCO3 in the crystalline phase [53]. 3.1.3 XRD analysis Fig. 6 shows the XRD diffractograms of the synthetized catalysts (Zn-BTCa and Zn-BTAlMg), their corresponding inorganic supports phase (CaCO3 and Al2O3 −Mg) and their corresponding database references (Al2O3, CaCO3, MgO and ZnO). Zn-BTAlMg catalyst peaks at 2θ = 37.7°, 45.9° and 66.9° are assigned to the characteristic signals of γ-alumina; peaks at 2θ = 42.8° and 62.2° are attributed to the MgO of the modified inorganic phase of the support [29,54]. Both synthetized catalysts present hexagonal quartzite poly-crystalline structure of ZnO, according to the standard reference file from the Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction (JCPDS, 36–1451) [55]. The catalyst Zn-BTAlMg shows peaks at 2θ = 32.1° and 36.5°, assigned to the (100) and (101) planes of ZnO [56]. The most relevant peaks of Zn-BTCa catalyst, are identified at 2θ = 22.9°, 29.4°, 35.8°, 39.4°, 43.0°, 47.3°, 48.4°, 57.4°, 60.8° and 64.8°, characteristic of the CaCO3 [29,54], and those of ZnO at 2θ = 32.1°, 36.5°, 57.2° and 68.5°, corresponding to the (100), (101), (110), and (112) planes, respectively. It is important to mention that the signal 2θ = 36.5° of ZnO, is overlapped in the Zn-BTCa catalyst by signals that coincide with the support. The signals corresponding to the composite supports (BTAl-Mg and BTCa) are the same as those of the corresponding inorganic phase (Al2O3 −Mg and CaCO3) due to the lack of signals from the amorphous polymeric structure. This was corroborated in previous investigations [4]. The crystallite sizes of the catalysts were estimated by XRD (dXRD ) by using the Debye-Scherrer correlation, Eq. (2), the deconvolution peak of ZnO at 2θ: 32.07° was used due to the overlap of the ZnO signals with those of the support. The crystallite sizes were 13.3 nm for Zn-BTCa and 3.2 nm for Zn-BTAlMg, these results agree with the results obtained by other authors [31]. Yadav et al. [55] prepared ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts and evaluated the effect of the pretreatment temperature during the synthesis of the materials. These authors state that at lower synthesis temperatures, smaller crystallite sizes are obtained: from 14.6 nm (673 K) to 37.9 nm (1273 K). In this work, the sizes are much lower (13.3 and 3.2 nm) because the temperature used in the synthesis step is much lower (363 K). On the other hand, it is known that the size of the crystallites, determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), depends on the used support. There is very little, almost no, information on ZnO/CaCO3. Similar results were found when supporting Ag on different supports; larger crystallite sizes were obtained when supporting Ag on CaCO3 than when it was supported on Al2O3 and Al2O3 −Mg [54]. 3.1.4 SEM-EDX analysis Fig. 7 shows the images of the elemental mapping by EDX in Zn-BTAlMg and Zn-BTCa. The polymer phase of the composite was obtained from the polymerization of BGMA (C28H36O8) and TEGDMA (C14H22O6), so in the SEM-EDX image the polymer phase will be represented by regions of high C content and very low O atoms content. On the other hand, in the inorganic phase made up of Al2O3 and CaCO3, through its elemental composition, it can be inferred that the high content of elemental O is associated with the presence of the elements Al and Ca. Then, It can be observed that the presence of ZnO particles is high on the inorganic phase and low on the organic phase of the support. This distribution is attributed to the dual hydrophilic/hydrophobic character, where the aqueous zinc solution has an affinity for the inorganic phase (hydrophilicity) as opposed to the hindrance presented by the polymeric phase (hydrophobicity). The dual hydrophilic/hydrophobic behavior of the support generates an egg-shell distribution with zones of ZnO particle accumulation associated with the inorganic phase of the support [4,28]. Fig. S5 – S7 of the Supporting Information show the mapping analysis of the elements present in both supports (BTAlMg and BTCa) and their respectively catalysts (Zn-BTAlMg and ZnBTCa). The EDX analysis results presented in Table S2 indicate that BTCa and Zn-BTCa solids contain C, O and Ca; Zn-BTAlMg and BTAlMg materials present C, O, Mg and Al. The Zn-BTAlMg solid presents a decrease of Al content, probably due to dealumination caused by NaOH treatment [52]. In Fig. S8 an irregular morphology with surface roughness of BTCa, Zn-BTCa, BTAlMg, and Zn-BTAlMg materials can be observed. 3.1.5 ICP and TEM analysis Zn loadings obtained by ICP-OES were 0.8 and 1.0 wt % for Zn-BTCa and Zn-BTAlMg, respectively. Fig. 8 shows the particle size distribution and images for Zn-BTAlMg and Zn-BTCa samples obtained by HRTEM. The average particle size (d TEM) determined by TEM and according to Eq. (3) were 175 nm for Zn-BTCa and 27.5 nm for Zn-BTAlMg catalyst. The particle diameter obtained in the Zn-BTCa catalyst is greater than that of the catalyst Zn-BTAlMg due to the low specific surface area of CaCO3 that favors the agglomeration of particles and indicates a difficult penetration of the ZnO particles into the support [57,58]. 3.1.6 XPS analysis The surface species in the synthetized catalysts were studied by XPS technique. Table 1 resumes the XPS results by showing the position of Zn 2p3/2 BE for each sample, also superficial elements of the supports Ca 2p3/2 and Mg 1s, and their superficial atomic N/Zn and Zn/M ratios, where N corresponds to nitrogen and M to Ca for Zn-BTCa or Al for Zn-BTAlMg. Fig. 9 presents the XPS spectra of Zn 2p doublets (2p3/2 and 2p1/2) signals (Fig. 9 a), Ca 2p3/2 (Fig. 9 b), O 1s signal (Fig. 9 c) and C 1s signal (Fig. 9 d) for Zn-BTCa. Meanwhile in Fig. 10 the XPS spectra of Zn 2p3/2 signal (Fig. 10 a), Al 2p (Fig. 10 b), O 1s signal (Fig. 10 c) and C 1s (Fig. 10 d) for Zn-BTAlMg are presented. In Fig. 9 a and Fig. 10a doublet for Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 was observed that is separated at 23 ± 0.2 eV, according to bibliography [30]. The deconvoluted BE values of Zn 2p3/2 indicate the presence of two superficial species in both catalysts. Main peak appears at 1022.1 eV and 1022.0 eV for Zn-BTCa and Zn-BTAlMg catalysts, respectively. The former signal can be attributed to Zn2+ electrodeficient species strongly interacting with the alumina forming ZnAl2O4 spinel on the surface catalysts [59]. The second peak of Zn 2p3/2 observed at 1023.9 and 1023.8 eV, indicates the existence of Zn2+ species of ZnO [59]. For Zn-BTCa, signals of O 1s (Fig. 9 c), Ca 2p (Fig. 9 b) and C 1s (Fig. 9 d) were analyzed for the study of surface species of the support. The O 1s spectrum have the peaks at 530.9 eV, 531.8 eV and 532.8 eV, which could be attributed to O2- in ZnO and CaCO3 (first peak); C=O (second peak) and CO (third peak) associated to organic phase from the composite material. In Ca 2p3/2 spectrum two peaks were observed then the deconvolution at a 347.3 (94 %) and 348.3 (6 %) eV, attributed to Ca2+ in CaCO3 and Ca(NO3)2, respectively [60]. The formation of Ca(NO3)2 could come from the Zn nitrate salt used during the preparation of the catalyst, this is confirmed by the presence of nitrogen from the results of N/Zn superficial atomic ratio (Table 2 ). C 1s presented 4 bands: at 284.6 eV attributed to a CC of the polymeric phase of the support: at 286.1 eV related to CO; at 288.2 eV in OC=O; and at 289.7 eV attributed to CO3 2- of CaCO3 (the inorganic phase of the support) [61]. In Zn-BTAlMg, BE of O 1s (Fig. 10 c), Al 2p and Mg 1s (Fig. 10 b), and C 1s (Fig. 10 d) were studied. Al 2p at 74.3 eV is attributed to Al2O3 of the inorganic phase of the support. Mg 1s at 1304.1 eV confirms the formation of MgAl2O4 spinel [59], indicating an intimate interaction with alumina during the preparation step. O 1s BEs peaks were observed at 530.6, 531.8 and 532.6 eV assigned to ZnO species (first peak), ZnAl2O4 species (second peak) and oxygen from composite material [59,61]. The main peak of C 1s at 284.6 eV is attributed to CC from the organic phase of the composite: 286.1, 288.0 and 288.5 eV corresponding to CO, C=O and OC=O species [61]. 3.2 Catalytic tests 3.2.1 Isomerization of β-pinene epoxide The effect of solvent was evaluated on the conversion and selectivity of the products in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide. Table 2 shows that the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide is a function of dielectric constant and solvent polarity. The conversion of β-pinene epoxide was evidenced in the presence of some polar and no-polar solvents; in the case of the tested no-polar solvent with the highest dielectric constant and with polar aprotic solvents with dielectric constants between 6.0 and 7.5, no β-pinene epoxide conversion was observed. The highest conversion was obtained using dimethyl carbonate as solvent; while myrtanal selectivity decreased in the following order: dimethyl carbonate = dioxane = tert‑butanol > acetone > cyclohexane = hexane. The tested no-polar solvents with similar dielectric constant gave the same myrtanal selectivity. The tested polar aprotic solvents with dieletric constant lower than 4.0 and the polar protic solvent favored myrtanal as the only product. The effect of solvents with different heterogeneous catalysts for the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide has been reported. The formation of myrtanal is favored in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide with catalysts with moderately acidic Lewis sites; the effect of solvent type on the selectivity toward myrtanal has been related to the chemical species in the catalytic systems and the stabilization and rearrangement of the intermediate carbocation [8]. While myrtanal is obtained using apolar solvents, the formation of myrtenol and perillyl alcohol is favored with the use of polar basic solvents [15]. The following order of conversion of β-pinene epoxide was achieved over Fe/MCM-41: acetonitrile > hexane > tert‑butanol > toluene = acetone > ethylacetate > cyclohexane > dioxane > tetrahydrofuran. While the highest selectivity towards myrtanal was obtained with acetonitrile (up to 90 %) [8]. On Colombian natural zeolite with dioxane, tetrahydrofuran or acetone no conversion of β-pinene epoxide was found, while with toluene and ethanol a conversion of 97 % and 95 % was respectively obtained [15]. For the best solvent, dimethyl carbonate, different amounts of catalyst (25, 35 and 50 mg) were evaluated, where it was observed that with an increase in the amount of catalyst (Zn-BTAlMg) from 25 mg to 50 mg it was found that the conversion of β-pinene epoxide increases from 16 % to 25 % and the selectivity towards myrtanal was 100 % for all the tested catalyst loadings. It has been reported the effect of the concentration of different heterogeneous catalysts, on Colombian natural zeolite with a low concentration of zeolite (2 mg mL-1) a conversion of 36 % was obtained with a selectivity towards perillyl alcohol (35 %) and myrtanal (28 %), when the catalyst concentration increased (25 mg mL-1) the conversion was 94 - 97 %, and the selectivity to perillyl alcohol increased from 33 % to 47 % [16]. Table 3 shows the conversion of β-pinene epoxide obtained at different times using 50 mg of catalyst over Zn-BTAlMg. A conversion of 89 % of β-pinene epoxide was achieved at 16 h. Selectivity towards myrtanal did not change with reaction time. Myrtanal formation from β-pinene epoxide isomerization can be related to the presence of Lewis acid sites [10] that were identified in the Zn-BTAlMg catalyst by Py-FTIR. The heterogeneity of the catalyst in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide was evaluated by leaching and reuse tests. No leaching of the catalyst synthesized with zinc impregnated composite material was evidenced. Fig. 11 a shows that the conversion of β-pinene epoxide after removing the catalyst from the reaction medium did not increase. When the catalyst was reused four times under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 11 b) it was found that the β-pinene epoxide conversion decreased 11 % respect to the first reaction; however, myrtanal selectivity did not significantly change. Fig. 12 shows a proposed reaction pathway for the formation of myrtanal from isomerization of β-pinene epoxide. First, there is a CO bond break because monoterpene epoxide adsorption and coordination over the Lewis acid site of the Zn-BTAlMg catalyst that corresponds to Zn2+ acid sites forming the tertiary carbocation. Then, the transference of the proton to the carbocation occurs. Next, there is a transference of hydrogen to the tertiary carbocation for forming the secondary carbocation. Finally, myrtanal is formed because the transfer of the lone pair of electrons of the oxygen for obtaining C=O bond [63]. 3.2.2 Oxidation of α-Pinene and limonene The oxidation of α-pinene and limonene was performed using the Payne system. Previous studies have evaluated the effect of the amount of acetone, H2O, H2O2 and acetonitrile with respect to the substrate; where an optimum mass ratio of 1: 3.2: 15.35: 19.17: 29.41:1.2 (substrate: H2O2: CH3CN: acetone: H2O: catalyst) was found using MgO as catalyst [16]. In this study, a lower mass ratio of substrate to H2O2 was used (1: 0.51), without modifying the other mass ratios respect to the substrate. The conversion and selectivity obtained over Zn-BTCa for the oxidation of α-pinene and limonene are shown in Table 4 and Table 5 , respectively. When BTCa was used as a catalyst for limonene and α-pinene oxidation, no substrate conversion was observed; however, when Zn-BTCa was the catalyst, oxidation of the substrates and one pot reaction in the case of α-pinene, was obtained. It is possible to obtain campholenic aldehyde in one pot reaction starting from α-pinene; it is observed that the reaction conditions favored epoxidation and isomerization of the formed epoxide, reaching a conversion of α-pinene of 73 %, with a selectivity to 90 % towards campholenic aldehyde in 24 h. The one pot reaction was not possible with other catalysts such as MgO. The total conversion of limonene was 36 % with a selectivity of 92 % and 8 % towards 1,2-limonene epoxide and 8,9-limonene epoxide, respectively, obtained at 14 h. The higher selectivity to 1,2-limonene epoxide is because this is the most substituted double bond, that is richest in electrons. It was reported 100 % selectivity of limonene epoxide over MgO (323 K, 0.5 h, limonene: H2O2: CH3CN: acetone: H2O: catalyst mass ratio of 1: 0.8: 15.7: 19.7: 30.3: 1.20) with limonene conversion of 40 %; however, limonene epoxide selectivity decreased with time favoring the diepoxide formation [17]. Oxidation of α-pinene using the Payne system was favored by the basicity of the Zn-BTCa catalyst that was identified by CO2-TPD and the formation of campholenic aldehyde is favored over Lewis acid sites [64], which were not identified in the solid by Py-FTIR. In order to identify the source of acidity in the medium that favored the isomerization of the formed epoxide, some blank reactions were performed. Table 6 shows that isomerization reaction into campholenic aldehyde only occurs in presence of water and the catalyst, which suggests that the acid sites are provided by H2O. This may be attributed to the hydrophilic-hydrophobic nature of the catalyst, which may be acting as both a catalyst and a phase transfer agent. Furthermore, the peroxyacetimidic acid that is the Payne intermediate species, seems to increase the medium acidity without affecting products selectivity. Furthermore, the pH of the reaction medium was around 6 at the beginning of the reaction, the pH decreased at around 4 after 4 h of reaction when the main product is the terpene epoxide (Table 4) and a pH between 7 and 8 was observed at 18 h of reaction when the main product is campholenic aldehyde. The pH variation indicates that a low pH the epoxide is favored and at higher pH the isomerization is preferred, which agree with the amphoteric characteristics of Zn, that behaves as a basic site under acid conditions and as acid site when the medium is basic. No leaching was detected using Zn-BTCa during α-pinene oxidation, because no increase in α-pinene conversion is evident after removal of the catalyst as shown in Fig. 13 a. The catalyst was reused four times under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 13 b), in which it is observed that the conversion of α-pinene decreased 7 %. In addition, the selectivity of the products does not show significant changes. Finally, the efficiency of the one-pot reaction activity of the catalyst towards campholenic aldehyde is not affected by the reuse of the catalyst. Fig. 14 shows a proposed reaction pathway for the formation of campholenic aldehyde from α-pinene oxidation, due to the amphoteric characteristics of supported zinc supported on BTCa; furthermore, the basicity of Zn-BTCa was identified by CO2-TPD. The epoxidation of α-pinene using the Payne system requires basic sites and the α-pinene epoxide isomerization to campholenic aldehyde is promoted by Lewis acid sites [27]. In the Payne system the intermediate oxidant peroxyacetimidic acid (C2H5O2 N) is formed by activation of H2O2 with acetonitrile through a nucleophilic attack by perhydroxyl anion species (HOO–) on the nitrile [18]. Initially, the presence of basic sites in Zn-BTCa, together with deprotonation of ZnO, favor the formation of peroxyacetimidic acid that is the oxidant agent. Then, α-pinene epoxide is activated on Zn2+ sites via the carbon–carbon double bond and reacts with the oxidant agent, giving α-pinene epoxide and acetamide [63]. Then, the epoxide adsorbs and coordinates onto the Lewis acid site (Zn2+) of Zn-BTCa, which causes the oxirane ring opening (forming a {CO–Zn} bridge) with the subsequent formation of a carbenium ion that may consecutively undergo rearrangements to produce campholenic aldehyde [65,66]. 4 Conclusions Two composite materials, BTAlMg and BTCa, were used as supports to synthesize supported Zn catalysts with unique properties. Zn was deposited by chemical method in order to obtain ZnO on the surface, which was corroborated by XPS and XRD techniques. ZnO crystallite sizes by XRD were 3.2 nm for Zn-BTAlMg and 13.3 nm for Zn-BTCa. Low particle size by TEM was obtained for Zn-BTAlMg (27.5 nm) than for Zn-BTCa (175 nm), indicating greater agglomeration of particles in the latter. The EDX-SEM technique show the existence of organic (BGMA and TEG polymer) and inorganic (CaCO3 and Al2O3 −Mg) phases of the composites. Additionally, the dual hydrophilic/hydrophobic behavior of the support generates an egg-shell distribution with zones of ZnO particle accumulation associated with the inorganic phase of the support. The Zn-BTCa composite catalysts exhibited promising results in the Payne system for the reaction of limonene and α-pinene. These results can be attributed to the hydrophobic and hydrophilic nature of the catalyst, as well as the presence of water, where the catalyst may be functioning as a phase transfer catalyst. This is reflected in the high conversion and selectivity values observed in the α-pinene epoxide reaction, using only water as the reaction medium. Test reactions used were the α-pinene and limonene oxidation, and the β-pinene epoxide isomerization. Zn-BTCa and Zn-BTAlMg solids showed mainly Lewis acid sites by Py-FTIR analysis that favor both reaction presented, since they allow better adsorption of the substrate which directly affects the selectivity in addition to the activity that is favored by the different states of Zn. The oxidation of α-pinene was achieved in a one pot reaction with the Zn-BTCa catalyst with a conversion of 73 % and a selectivity towards campholenic aldehyde of 90 %. The oxidation of limonene over Zn-BTCa yielded a conversion of 36 % with a selectivity of 92 % and 8 % towards 1,2-limonene epoxide and 8,9-limonene epoxide, respectively. The isomerization of β-pinene epoxide over Zn-BTAlMg was tested with polar and non-polar solvents; when dimethyl carbonate (polar) was used as solvent, 89 % β-pinene epoxide conversion and 100 % selectivity to myrtanal were obtained. The synthesized catalysts did not show leaching in the evaluated catalytic reactions. No leaching was observed from Zn-BTAlMg and Zn-BTCa catalysts in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide and the oxidation of α-pinene, respectively; furthermore, after four reuses, the selectivity of the products did not present significant changes, the α-pinene and β-pinene epoxide conversion decreased 7 % and 11 %, respectively. Finally, heterogeneous catalysts were achieved of a composite nature, showed a high impact on the catalytic results during the terpene oxidation reactions. Zn catalysts on composite material are a promising alternative for the selective transformation of terpenes into high value-added products. coredata.dc:description: In this work, zinc supported composite catalysts were evaluated in the isomerization of β-pinene epoxide, limonene oxidation, and one pot synthesis of campholenic aldehyde from α-pinene. The composites materials were synthesized using CaCO3 and a mixture of aluminium and magnesium sources as the inorganic phases and the bisphenol A glycerolate dimethacrylate / triethylene glycol dimethacrylate polymerized mixture as the polymeric organic phases. The materials were characterized by NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, XRD, Py-FTIR, XPS, ICP, TEM and SEM-EDX. Mainly Lewis acid sites were identified by Py-FTIR analysis of BTAlMg and Zn-BTAlMg. The basicity of BTCa and Zn-BTCa materials was identified by CO2-TPD. Over Zn-BTCa, α-pinene conversion of 73 % and campholenic aldehyde selectivity of 90 % were obtained. The oxidation of limonene over Zn-BTCa yielded a conversion of 36 % with a selectivity of 92 % and 8 % towards 1,2-limonene epoxide and 8,9-limonene epoxide, respectively. The isomerization of β-pinene epoxide over Zn-BTAlMg with dimethyl carbonate, gave 89 % β-pinene epoxide conversion and 100 % selectivity to myrtanal. The synthesized catalysts did not show leaching under tested catalytic reactions. After four reuses, the product selectivity did not significantly changed and the conversion decreased 7 % and 11 % in the oxidation of α-pinene and isomerization of β-pinene epoxide, respectively.
